class="ReferencedArticles"></section><div class="PageDivider"></div><div class="Abstracts u-font-serif" id="abstracts"><div class="abstract author-highlights" id="ab0010" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Highlights</h2><div id="as0010"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0065"><ul class="list"><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0005">A Co-free biphasic (P2/O3) layered NFM cathode is synthesized and dual surface &amp; structural modifications are performed.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0010">Bi<sup>5+</sup> is doped into pure NFM to tune the P2/O3 phase, whereas, Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> is coated on Bi<sup>5+</sup>-doped NFM to modify the surface.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0015">Na-storage and diffusion analysis revels that, dual modification increases D<sub>Na</sub>+ value and capacitive nature in BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0020">BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> cathode renders ~180 mAh g<sup>-1</sup> capacity with 73% capacity retention of initial capacity.</div></span></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="abstract author" id="ab0005" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Abstract</h2><div id="as0005"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0060">A cobalt-free biphasic (P2/O3) layered Na[Ni<sub>0.55</sub>Mn<sub>0.35</sub>Fe<sub>0.1</sub>]O<sub>2</sub><span> (NFM) <a href="/topics/materials-science/cathode-material" title="Learn more about cathode material from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">cathode material</a> has been synthesized and dual surface and structural modifications have been performed. Bi</span><sup>5+</sup> is doped into pure NFM in order to tune the P2/O3 phase, whereas, a thin layer of Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> is coated on surface of the Bi<sup>5+</sup><span>-doped NFM (BNFM) for surface modification. The structure, morphology, and <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performance</a> of prepared samples are analyzed and compared by various characterization techniques. The pristine NFM cathode exhibits the specific discharge capacity of 170 mAh g</span><sup>−1</sup>, while Bi-doped cathode exhibits 181 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, and Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> coated cathode renders 180 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>. It is observed that, pristine NFM cathode suffers rapid capacity degradation and nearly ~80&nbsp;% capacity loss within first 250&nbsp;cycles. After 1000&nbsp;cycles, BNFM shows 47&nbsp;% capacity retention, while, Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> coated BNFM (BNMF@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>) shows 73&nbsp;% capacity retention of initial capacity. This improvement in the rate capability is obtained due to the effect of Bi-doping and Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> coating, where, former enlarges interlayer spacing and latter provides the ionic conducting channel as well as protects the particle from the contact of the electrolyte. The combined effect of Bi-doping and Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> coating facilitates fast diffusion of Na-ions within the transition metal layers resulting in superior rate capability.</div></div></div></div><ul id="issue-navigation" class="issue-navigation u-margin-s-bottom u-bg-grey1"><li class="previous move-left u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-left"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-left" href="/science/article/pii/S2352152X23033261"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-left"><path d="M1 61l45-45 7 7-38 38 38 38-7 7z"></path></svg><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Previous <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span></a></li><li class="next move-right u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-right"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-right" href="/science/article/pii/S2352152X23033558"><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Next <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg></a></li></ul><div class="Keywords u-font-serif"><div id="ks0005" class="keywords-section"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Keywords</h2><div id="kw0005" class="keyword"><span id="tx0010">Sodium-ion battery</span></div><div id="kw0010" class="keyword"><span id="tx0015">Cobalt free layered Na[Ni<sub>0.55</sub>Mn<sub>0.35</sub>Fe<sub>0.1</sub>]O<sub>2</sub> cathode</span></div><div id="kw0015" class="keyword"><span id="tx0020">Bi<sup>5+</sup>-doping</span></div><div id="kw0020" class="keyword"><span id="tx0025">Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> coating</span></div><div id="kw0025" class="keyword"><span id="tx0030">High capacity retention</span></div></div></div><div class="Body u-font-serif" id="body"><div><section id="s0005"><h2 id="st0025" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">1. Introduction</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0030"><span><span>Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have dominated the energy storage market for decades due to their high <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/flux-density" title="Learn more about energy density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy density</a> and long cycle life. However, the growing demand for electric vehicles and </span><a href="/topics/engineering/renewable-energy-storage" title="Learn more about renewable energy storage from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">renewable energy storage</a><span><span> has prompted researchers to explore alternative <a href="/topics/engineering/battery-electrochemical-energy-engineering" title="Learn more about battery from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">battery</a><span> chemistries that are more sustainable and cost-effective. Moreover, cobalt-based materials are the most widely used <a href="/topics/materials-science/cathode-material" title="Learn more about cathode materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">cathode materials</a><span> in LIBs, but their limited supply, high cost, and environmental concerns have provoked researchers to seek cobalt-free alternatives. In recent years, sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) have emerged as a promising alternative to lithium-ion batteries due to the abundance and low cost of <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> resources as well as the similarity of their </span></span></span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemistry" title="Learn more about electrochemistry from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemistry</a> to lithium-ion batteries [</span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0005" name="bbb0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">1</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0010" name="bbb0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">2</span></span></a>]. Because the cathode is a significant component of SIBs and plays a crucial role in their performance, therefore, the design of cathode materials that can deliver high capacity, good rate capability, and long cycle life is one of the key challenges for the development of high-performance sodium-ion batteries [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0005" name="bbb0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">1</span></span></a><span><span>]. A large number of SIB electrodes, including polyanionic compounds, organic materials and 2D layered <a href="/topics/materials-science/oxide-compound" title="Learn more about oxides from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxides</a> have been widely explored. Among them, 2D layered </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/transition-metal-oxide" title="Learn more about transition metal oxides from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">transition metal oxides</a> (NaNi</span><sub>x</sub>Co<sub>y</sub>Mn<sub>1-x-y</sub>O<sub>2</sub>), are particularly used as promising cathodes in sodium-ion batteries [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0015" name="bbb0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">3</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0020" name="bbb0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">4</span></span></a><span>]. These compounds offer high gravimetric <a href="/topics/materials-science/energy-density" title="Learn more about energy density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy density</a>, long cycling life, and cost-effectiveness, making them an attractive option. These materials are classified into two groups, prismatic (P type: P2, P3, and P'2) and octahedral (O type: O2 and O3), based on their sodium storage sites and structures [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0020" name="bbb0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[4]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0025" name="bbb0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[5]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0030" name="bbb0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[6]</span></span></a>]. While the P2-type materials have good reversible capacity and stable structure, but their initial sodium deficiency limits their utility in practical cells. On the other hand, O3-type materials having a crystal structure similar to LiCoO<sub>2</sub> are suitable for use in full cells [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0035" name="bbb0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[7]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0040" name="bbb0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[8]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0045" name="bbb0045" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0045"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[9]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0050" name="bbb0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[10]</span></span></a>]. However, concerns over cobalt's environmental impact and high cost have led to the development of a new class of material, NFM (NaNi<sub>x</sub>Fe<sub>y</sub>Mn<sub>1-x-y</sub>O<sub>2</sub><span>), which completely replaces cobalt with iron. Since iron is abundant, inexpensive and nontoxic as compared to cobalt, iron-based cathode has the potential to make SIBs more affordable, efficient, and environmentally friendly, which could help to accelerate their adoption in various <a href="/topics/engineering/energy-storage-application" title="Learn more about energy storage applications from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy storage applications</a> [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0055" name="bbb0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[11]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0060" name="bbb0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[12]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0065" name="bbb0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[13]</span></span></a><span>]. Apart from these, layered transition metal oxides suffer from some inherent problems such as limited rate capability and sluggish reaction kinetics, which are contributed by several factors including Jahn-Teller distortion, large cell volume changes and multi-phase <a href="/topics/materials-science/redox-process" title="Learn more about redox reactions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">redox reactions</a> [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0070" name="bbb0070" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0070"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[14]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0075" name="bbb0075" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0075"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[15]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0080" name="bbb0080" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0080"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[16]</span></span></a>]. In P2 type cathodes, the structural destruction is usually caused by P2-O2 transition during Na<sup>+</sup><span>-intercalation/deintercalation. Moreover, high reactivity of Ni in O3 type cathode materials leads to the unfavorable side reactions resulting in unstable <a href="/topics/engineering/solid-electrolyte-interface" title="Learn more about solid electrolyte interface from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">solid electrolyte interface</a> (SEI) [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0040" name="bbb0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">8</span></span></a><span>]. In particular, the intrinsic features of single phase layered oxides make it challenging to realize overall excellent <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performance</a> of cathode materials. Biphasic materials have recently been employed in a number of inspiring works that not only integrate the benefits of both phases but also counteract their inherent drawbacks such as, P2/O3, P2/P3, etc. [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0085" name="bbb0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">17</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0090" name="bbb0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">18</span></span></a>] Zhang et al. reported biphasic Na<sub>x</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> cathode with 87 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 4&nbsp;A g<sup>−1</sup> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0085" name="bbb0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">17</span></span></a>]. Sun et al. reported layered/tunnel biphasic layered cathode with 81&nbsp;% P2-phase and 19&nbsp;% tunnel phase with 108.3 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 600&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0095" name="bbb0095" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0095"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">19</span></span></a>]. Similarly, Mishra et al. reported biphasic O3/P2 Na-NMC cathode (78.11&nbsp;% O3 and 21.88&nbsp;% P2 phase) with capacity 151 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0040" name="bbb0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">8</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0035"><span>Although altering the P2/O3 phase results in remarkable electrochemical performance, layered <a href="/topics/engineering/oxide-cathode" title="Learn more about oxide cathodes from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxide cathodes</a><span> also suffer from a number of additional drawbacks. During the process of sodiation/desodiation, aeolotropic lattice changes and mechanical stress cause the formation of microcracks inside and on the surface of the cathode at the cathode <a href="/topics/engineering/electrolyte-interface" title="Learn more about electrolyte interface from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrolyte interface</a> (CEI). As a result, the electrolyte infiltrates excessively through the microcracks into the interior of the cathode particles along the grain boundaries, leading to more surface degradation and uncontrolled CEI formation [</span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0100" name="bbb0100" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0100"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">20</span></span></a><span>]. To address these inherent drawbacks of layered oxide cathodes, various methodologies have been implemented including structural modulation through doping or substitution of elements as well as surface engineering of the cathode particles. These approaches aim to stabilize the cathode's structure, regulate the formation of controlled CEI, and achieve sufficient ionic and <a href="/topics/engineering/electronic-conductivity" title="Learn more about electronic conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electronic conductivity</a>. Doping with various elements including Mg, Ti, Cu, Mo, etc., considerably enhanced the structure and conductivity, leading to improved performance [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0105" name="bbb0105" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0105"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[21]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0110" name="bbb0110" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0110"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[22]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0115" name="bbb0115" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0115"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[23]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0120" name="bbb0120" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0120"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[24]</span></span></a><span><span>]. However, they are not very efficient in either increasing the surface <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffusivity" title="Learn more about diffusivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusivity</a> of </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium-ion" title="Learn more about sodium ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium ions</a><span> in the cathode or shielding the particles from unintended side reactions. For this purpose, surface modification has been found to be a promising method, as demonstrated by several studies. <a href="/topics/engineering/layer-coating" title="Learn more about Coating layers from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Coating layers</a><span> can protect cathode materials from hydrofluoric acid attack by separating them from the electrolyte, as well as reduce oxygen loss by decreasing the activity of <a href="/topics/engineering/oxygen-ion" title="Learn more about oxygen ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxygen ions</a><span> and retaining oxygen-ion vacancies. Numerous <a href="/topics/engineering/coating-material" title="Learn more about coating materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">coating materials</a> have been employed in prior research including metallic phosphates, oxides, fluorides, etc. [</span></span></span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0100" name="bbb0100" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0100"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">20</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0125" name="bbb0125" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0125"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[25]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0130" name="bbb0130" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0130"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[26]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0135" name="bbb0135" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0135"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[27]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0140" name="bbb0140" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0140"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[28]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0145" name="bbb0145" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0145"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[29]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0150" name="bbb0150" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0150"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[30]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0155" name="bbb0155" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0155"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[31]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0160" name="bbb0160" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0160"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[32]</span></span></a>]<strong>.</strong> Although, effectiveness of doping and coating is reported in various articles. However, most of these studies report the effect of doping as well as coating separately. These approaches are not adequate on its own to reduce capacity deterioration in layered cathode material by addressing all aforementioned issues simultaneously. Therefore, stabilizing particle surfaces and crystal structure concurrently is important to simultaneously address these intrinsic limitations.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0040">Herein, we present a suitable P2/O3 biphasic cobalt free layered Na[Ni<sub>0.55</sub>Mn<sub>0.35</sub>Fe<sub>0.1</sub>]O<sub>2</sub> cathode and content of P2/O3 phases are tuned by 5&nbsp;% Bi-doping using simple one pot solid-state reaction method. Further, 2&nbsp;% Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> coating has been employed on Bi-doped Na[Ni<sub>0.55</sub>Mn<sub>0.30</sub>Bi<sub>0.05</sub>Fe<sub>0.1</sub>]O<sub>2</sub> for surface modification. The reason behind choosing Bi<sup>5+</sup><span> in NFM is the <a href="/topics/engineering/ionic-radius" title="Learn more about ionic radii from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ionic radii</a> of Bi</span><sup>5+</sup> (0.90&nbsp;Å), which is slightly higher but close to Mn<sup>4+</sup> (0.80&nbsp;Å). It is supposed that, after incorporation of Bi in NFM lattice, the interlayer spacing should increase, which is reported in various literatures [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0165" name="bbb0165" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0165"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[33]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0170" name="bbb0170" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0170"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[34]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0175" name="bbb0175" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0175"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[35]</span></span></a>]. Also, the coating material Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>, is widely used in electric ceramics, solid electrolytes, and <a href="/topics/materials-science/photoelectric-material" title="Learn more about photoelectric materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">photoelectric materials</a> due to its unique physical properties and crystal structure [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0180" name="bbb0180" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0180"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">36</span></span></a>]. Pure Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span><span> has a <a href="/topics/engineering/monoclinic" title="Learn more about monoclinic from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">monoclinic</a> phase at room temperature with 25&nbsp;% </span><a href="/topics/engineering/oxygen-vacancy" title="Learn more about oxygen vacancies from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxygen vacancies</a>, suggesting that it may act as an effective oxygen storage material. Bi</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span> possesses an ordered defect fluorite structure with Bi layers arranged parallel to the (100) plane and alternating with O layers, providing rapid <a href="/topics/engineering/diffusion-path" title="Learn more about diffusion paths from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion paths</a> for sodium ions [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0185" name="bbb0185" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0185"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">37</span></span></a>]. Additionally, Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> has the highest ion conductivity (10 mS cm<sup>−1</sup><span> at 500&nbsp;°C) among all <a href="/topics/engineering/oxide-ion-conductor" title="Learn more about oxide ion conductors from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxide ion conductors</a>, which may enhance the rate capability of cathode materials. Bi</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span> has been shown to be an effective <a href="/topics/engineering/surface-coating" title="Learn more about surface coating from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">surface coating</a> material for improving the columbic efficiency, cyclability, and rate capability of lithium spinel oxides [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0190" name="bbb0190" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0190"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">38</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0195" name="bbb0195" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0195"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">39</span></span></a>]. Considering aforementioned discussions, it is supposed that this novel approach of simultaneous Bi-doping in bulk and Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span> coating on the surface can effectively overcome the inherent drawbacks, making NFM as very sustainable, effective and cobalt free cathode material for <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/sodium-ion-batteries" title="Learn more about sodium ion batteries from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium ion batteries</a>.</span></div></section><section id="s0010"><h2 id="st0030" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Experimental section</h2><section id="s0015"><h3 id="st0035" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.1. Materials used</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0045"><span>The <a href="/topics/materials-science/transition-metal-oxide" title="Learn more about transition metal oxides from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">transition metal oxides</a> NiO (~99.99&nbsp;%), MnO (99.0&nbsp;%), Fe</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> (~95&nbsp;%), and Bi(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub> (~98&nbsp;%) are used as precursors and from Sigma Aldrich and SRL chemical. Conducting carbon black (super P), Al-metal foil (thickness&nbsp;~&nbsp;15&nbsp;μm), and CR-2032 type coin cells are purchased from MTI Corporation. Anhydrous <em>N</em>-methyl-2-pyrrolidonel (NMP) (~99.5&nbsp;%), binder PVdF (M.W. ~534,000&nbsp;g&nbsp;m<sup>−1</sup>), sodium cubes (in mineral oil, 99.9&nbsp;% trace metal basis), Na<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub><span> and Whatman Glass <a href="/topics/engineering/microfibres" title="Learn more about microfiber from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">microfiber</a> separator (GF/F, pore size ~0.7&nbsp;μm), NaClO</span><sub>4,</sub><span> EC, DEC are purchased from Sigma Aldrich, <a href="/topics/engineering/germany" title="Learn more about Germany from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Germany</a>. Air and moisture sensitive chemicals are stored inside Ar-gas filled glove box (MBRAUN ABstar, O</span><sub>2</sub>&nbsp;&lt;&nbsp;0.5&nbsp;ppm, H<sub>2</sub>O&nbsp;&lt;&nbsp;0.5&nbsp;ppm).</div></section><section id="s0020"><h3 id="st0040" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.2. Synthesis of pristine Na[Ni<sub>0.55</sub>Mn<sub>0.35</sub>Fe<sub>0.1</sub>]O<sub>2</sub> and Bi-doped Na[Ni<sub>0.55</sub>Mn<sub>0.30</sub>Bi<sub>0.05</sub>Fe<sub>0.1</sub>]O<sub>2</sub></h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0050">The synthesis of pristine Na[Ni<sub>0.55</sub>Mn<sub>0.35</sub>Fe<sub>0.1</sub>]O<sub>2</sub> and Bi doped Na[Ni<sub>0.55</sub>Mn<sub>0.30</sub> Bi<sub>0.05</sub>Fe<sub>0.1</sub>]O<sub>2</sub><span><span> are performed by solid-state method. The stochiometric quantity of transition metal oxides as well as doping precursors is adequately blended and crushed for 2&nbsp;h using a mortar and pestle. The resultant mixtures are then submerged in ethanol to form a slurry prior to getting transferred to the milling bench using zirconia balls and a jar and milled at 400&nbsp;rpm for 24&nbsp;h. The mixtures are recovered after <a href="/topics/engineering/ball-milling" title="Learn more about ball milling from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ball milling</a> by washing the vessel and the balls with ethanol and placed in a vacuum oven to evaporate any trace of ethanol. Now, the resulting materials are pre-calcined at 450&nbsp;°C for 5&nbsp;h followed by </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/calcination" title="Learn more about calcination from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">calcination</a><span> at 900&nbsp;°C for 12&nbsp;h in <a href="/topics/engineering/muffle" title="Learn more about muffle from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">muffle</a> furnace in ambient atmosphere to obtain pristine Na[Ni</span></span><sub>0.55</sub>Mn<sub>0.35</sub>Fe<sub>0.1</sub>]O<sub>2</sub> and Bi-doped Na[Ni<sub>0.55</sub>Mn<sub>0.30</sub> Bi<sub>0.05</sub>Fe<sub>0.1</sub>]O<sub>2</sub><span> <a href="/topics/materials-science/cathode-material" title="Learn more about cathode materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">cathode materials</a> which are named as NFM and BNFM, respectively.</span></div></section><section id="s0025"><h3 id="st0045" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.3. Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> coating on Bi-doped Na[Ni<sub>0.55</sub>Mn<sub>0.30</sub> Bi<sub>0.05</sub>Fe<sub>0.1</sub>]O<sub>2</sub> cathode</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0055"><span>A wet chemical <a href="/topics/materials-science/coating-process" title="Learn more about coating process from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">coating process</a> is employed to coat Bi</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> on the surface of Bi-doped Na[Ni<sub>0.55</sub>Mn<sub>0.30</sub>Bi<sub>0.05</sub>Fe<sub>0.1</sub>]O<sub>2</sub> (BNFM) cathode, which involved 2&nbsp;wt% Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> coating on BNFM particles. The stoichiometric amounts of Bi(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub>·5H<sub>2</sub>O (99&nbsp;%) are dissolved in distilled water and the resulting solution is used to disperse the already prepared BNFM powders. Few amounts of ammonium hydroxide (NH<sub>4</sub>OH) are then added dropwise to the mixture and the resulting product is stirred at 80&nbsp;°C to evaporate the water. The resulting product is dried and sintered in air at 500&nbsp;°C for 5&nbsp;h to produce the Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>-coated BNFM cathode, which is named BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>.</div></section><section id="s0030"><h3 id="st0050" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.4. Sample characterizations</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0060"><span>The synthesized cathode materials are subjected to various analytical techniques to gain insight into their structural, morphological, and electronic properties. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis is performed using PANalytical's X'Pert PRO <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffractometers" title="Learn more about diffractometer from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffractometer</a> over a 2Ɵ range of 10–80°, with a step size of 0.026° and a scan rate of 5° min</span><sup>−1</sup><span><span><span>. The <a href="/topics/materials-science/surface-morphology" title="Learn more about surface morphology from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">surface morphology</a> of the samples is examined using scanning electron microscopy (EVO-scanning </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electron-microscope" title="Learn more about electron microscope from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electron microscope</a><span> MA15/18), while <a href="/topics/materials-science/transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about transmission electron microscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">transmission electron microscopy</a> (TF20: Tecnai G2 200kV TEM (FEI)) is employed to visualize the </span></span><a href="/topics/engineering/layer-coating" title="Learn more about coating layers from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">coating layers</a>. To investigate the electronic state of transition metal oxides, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, K-ALPHA thermoscientific) is utilized.</span></div></section><section id="s0035"><h3 id="st0055" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.5. Electrochemical measurements</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0065"><span><span>The electrodes are prepared by mixing active materials (NFM, BNFM, and BNFM@RGO), Super-P, and PVdF binder in NMP (80:10:10; wt. ratio) using a vacuum <a href="/topics/engineering/mixers-machinery" title="Learn more about mixer from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">mixer</a> (MTI SFM-7) for 6&nbsp;h to produce slurry. The resulting slurry is uniformly coated on </span><a href="/topics/engineering/aluminum-foil" title="Learn more about aluminium foil from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">aluminium foil</a><span> with an automatic <a href="/topics/materials-science/thick-films" title="Learn more about thick film from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">thick film</a> coater (MSK-AFA-II-VC-FH), dried at 110&nbsp;°C overnight, and cut into disks with a diameter of 13&nbsp;mm. The active material mass loading in the cathode is ~3.3&nbsp;mg&nbsp;cm</span></span><sup>−2</sup>. For half-cell testing, CR2032-type coin cells containing the prepared electrodes and 1&nbsp;M NaClO<sub>4</sub><span><span><span> in (EC, DEC, 1:1) with 5&nbsp;% FEC electrolyte are prepared in an argon-filled glove box, with a Whatman glass <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/microfiber" title="Learn more about microfiber from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">microfiber</a> separator. The metallic sodium discs are used as the </span><a href="/topics/engineering/negative-electrode" title="Learn more about negative electrode from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">negative electrode</a>. The prepared cells are allowed to stabilize for 12&nbsp;h before electrochemical characterization. </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about Cyclic voltammetry from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Cyclic voltammetry</a><span> (CV) and <a href="/topics/materials-science/dielectric-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about electrochemical impedance spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical impedance spectroscopy</a> (EIS) analysis are performed by using electrochemical work station AUTOLAB PGSTAT 302&nbsp;N, while, the charge/discharge and cycling performance are measured by electrochemical workstation (ARBIN LBT21084, SN: 208575) at ambient temperature.</span></span></div></section></section><section id="s0040"><h2 id="st0060" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Results and discussion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0070">The pristine and Bi-doped NFM are synthesized by facile one pot solid-state reaction, while, Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span> coating is performed by wet <a href="/topics/materials-science/chemical-processing" title="Learn more about chemical method from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">chemical method</a>, as shown schematically in the </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>(a). X-ray diffraction analysis (XRD) is used to perform structural analysis on the cathode powders that are prepared, namely NFM, BNFM, and BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><span>(b) illustrates the <a href="/topics/engineering/ray-diffraction" title="Learn more about XRD from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD</a> patterns of the pristine NFM, Bi-doped BNFM, and Bi</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> coated BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3.</sub> All the three samples show well defined crystalline peaks which are indexed on the basis of α-NaFeO<sub>2</sub> typical layer structure [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0200" name="bbb0200" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0200"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">40</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0205" name="bbb0205" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0205"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">41</span></span></a><span>]. <a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-diffraction" title="Learn more about XRD from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD</a> pattern reveals that prepared samples have coexistence of O3-phase (space group: </span><em>R-3m</em>) as well as P2-type phase (space group: <em>P6</em><sub><em>3</em></sub><em>/mmc</em>) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0075" name="bbb0075" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0075"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">15</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0210" name="bbb0210" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0210"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">42</span></span></a>]. Rietveld profile matching, as illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><span>(d), is used to extract quantitative structural information for both phases. Refined <a href="/topics/engineering/x-ray-diffraction-pattern" title="Learn more about XRD patterns from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD patterns</a> of all the three samples confirm the co-existence of the binary phases (O3 as well as P2 phases) and the intensity of most intense peaks (I</span><sub>(003)O3</sub> of O3 phase and I<sub>(102)P2</sub> of P2 phase) is used to determine the respective phase fractions (in %) using the following equations.<span class="display"><span id="fo0005" class="formula"><span class="label">(1)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-16-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mtext xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32" x="1001" y="0"></use></g><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-29" x="1891" y="0"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1140,0)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-50"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1516,0)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g></g></g></g></g><g is="true" is="true">100</mn></math></script></span></span></span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0005"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X23034576-gr1.jpg" height="715" alt="Fig. 1" aria-describedby="ca0005"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X23034576-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (2MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (2MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X23034576-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="ca0005"><p id="sp0005"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. (a) Schematic representation of synthesis, structural and surface modification of biphasic cobalt-free Na[Ni<sub>0.55</sub>Mn<sub>0.35</sub>Fe<sub>0.1</sub>]O<sub>2</sub><span><span> cathode, (b) <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffraction-pattern" title="Learn more about XRD pattern from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD pattern</a><span>, (c) shifting of 003 peak towards lower angle, (d) <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/rietveld-refinement" title="Learn more about Rietveld refinement from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Rietveld refinement</a> profile matching, and (e-g) SEM </span></span><a href="/topics/engineering/micrograph" title="Learn more about micrographs from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">micrographs</a> of prepared NFM, BNFM and BNFM@Bi</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> cathodes, respectively.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0075">All the refined cell parameters and relative phase fractions for the three samples are listed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#t0005" name="bt0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="t0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 1</span></span></a>. From this result, it is observed that, in pristine NFM, O3 phase is dominant with phase fraction of ~78.86&nbsp;%, whereas, P2 phase is ~21.14&nbsp;%. But, when Bi<sup>5+</sup> is introduced, the P2-content increased up to ~47.14&nbsp;%, while, O3 phase remained ~52.86&nbsp;% in BNFM sample. This structural change is accompanied with the introduction of Bi<sup>5+</sup> at the site of Mn<sup>4+</sup>. Additionally, it is noted that the addition of Bi<sup>5+</sup> causes the 003 peak to shift towards a lower angle (as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>(c)), which increases ‘c’ value and enhances interlayer spacing in the BNFM cathode, which facilitates more and easier Na-ion diffusion and increases capacity [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0100" name="bbb0100" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0100"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">20</span></span></a>]. After Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> coating, there is no obvious change observed in BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> sample except two minor peaks at positions 47.78 and 53.90°, which are related to the Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> coating layer [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0215" name="bbb0215" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0215"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">43</span></span></a><span>]. The <a href="/topics/materials-science/surface-morphology" title="Learn more about surface morphology from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">surface morphology</a> of NFM, BNFM and BNFM@Bi</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> samples is investigated by SEM technique. According to SEM images, the pure NFM and Bi-doped BNFM cathodes exhibit aggregated, irregularly shaped, and non-spherical particles, whereas, Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> coated NFM possess comparatively less agglomerated particles (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><span> (e-g)). Moreover, the average <a href="/topics/materials-science/particle-size-analysis" title="Learn more about particle size distribution from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">particle size distribution</a><span><span>, <a href="/topics/materials-science/energy-dispersive-x-ray-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about EDX from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">EDX</a> spectra and elemental mapping analysis of pure NFM and Bi-doped BNFM are shown in the </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/electrospray-ionization" title="Learn more about ESI from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ESI</a> Figs. (S1 &amp; S2), respectively. Both samples show average particle size distributions of 1.8&nbsp;μm and 0.67&nbsp;μm, respectively. However, BNFM@Bi</span></span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span> shows the smaller <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/particle-size-distribution" title="Learn more about particle size distribution from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">particle size distribution</a> of 0.63&nbsp;μm as shown in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a> (a). The Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> coating layer on the surface of NFM particles avoids the interaction between primary particles leading to less agglomeration. Moreover, the peaks corresponding to the elements Ni, Mn, Fe, Na and O are clearly visible in the spectrum of NFM, while, BNFM and BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> samples show the peaks corresponding to Bi elements in addition to Ni, Mn, Fe, Na and O confirming the presence of Bi in doped as well as Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> coated samples. The elemental mapping further confirms the uniform distribution of Na, Ni, Mn, Fe and O elements in NFM, while, in BNFM and BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> samples, the uniform distribution of Bi elements is also observed, which further confirms the presence of these elements in Bi-doped as well as Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> coated samples.</div><div class="tables frame-topbot rowsep-0 colsep-0" id="t0005"><span class="captions text-s"><span id="ca0045"><p id="sp0045"><span class="label">Table 1</span>. <span>The refined values and <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/lattice-parameter" title="Learn more about lattice parameters from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">lattice parameters</a> for NFM, BNFM and BNFM@Bi</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span> after <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/rietveld-refinement" title="Learn more about Rietveld refinement from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.268ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-33"></use><use is="true">×</mo></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-19"><math><mn is="true">3.74</mn><mo class="align-char">6.41</td><td class="align-char">203.0</td><td class="align-char">153.0</td><td>8.8<span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-20-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>0</mn><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xD7;</mo></math>" class="align-char">32.20</td><td class="align-char">5.39</td><td class="align-char">83.3</td><td class="align-char">102.0</td><td>1.09<span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-22-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xD7;</mo></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.808ex" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo is="true">×</mo></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-22"><math><mo is="true">×</mo></math></script></span>10<sup>−8</sup></td><td>1.12<span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-23-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xD7;</mo></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.808ex" height="1.46ex" viewBox="0 -569.8 778.5 628.5" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align:
