src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X23034576-gr2.jpg" height="482" alt="Fig. 2" aria-describedby="ca0010"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X23034576-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (2MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (2MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X23034576-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="ca0010"><p id="sp0010"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. <span>(a) Average <a href="/topics/materials-science/particle-size-analysis" title="Learn more about particle size distribution from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">particle size distribution</a><span>, (b) <a href="/topics/materials-science/energy-dispersive-x-ray-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about EDX from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">EDX</a> spectrum and (c) the corresponding area for EDX and elemental mapping analysis, d) Elemental mapping of Bi</span></span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> coated Bi-doped BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> cathode.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0080">Furthermore, the TEM analysis is performed to investigate the microstructures of the co-existence of binary phases as well as to visualize the presence of coating layer on the surface of Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>-coated cathode particles. The TEM images of the three samples are shown in the ESI Fig. S3, whereas, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. 3</span></span></a> (a-c), display the magnified TEM images of NFM, BNFM and BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> samples, respectively. It is observed that, the pristine NFM and Bi-doped NFM cathode particles have smooth surface with sharp and clear edges (as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>(a, b)), whereas, BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> cathode contains a uniform thin layer of Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> (as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><span><span>(c)) of average thickness&nbsp;~&nbsp;6&nbsp;nm. The HR-TEM images with inverse <a href="/topics/engineering/fast-fourier-transform" title="Learn more about fast Fourier transform from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">fast Fourier transform</a> (IFFT) patterns (in the inset) and selected area </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electron-diffraction" title="Learn more about electron diffraction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electron diffraction</a> (SAED) patterns of the selected regions are displayed in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a> (d-f) and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a> (g-i), respectively. The IFFT pattern of NFM sample presents a clear interplanar lattice spacing of 0.52&nbsp;nm, which is consistent with the (003) plane of hexagonal layered structure with the space group <em>R -3 m</em> while, after Bi-doping, the interplanar spacing is significantly increased up to 0.61&nbsp;nm in BNFM sample (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a> (d, e)). This increase in interlayer spacing leads to easy diffusion along with enhanced storage of Na-ions, which boosts capacity and high-rate capabilities. Furthermore, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>(f), shows the HR-TEM images of in Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> coating layer with the interlayer spacing of 0.50&nbsp;nm, which is compatible for the transportation of Na-ions. The SAED pattern of the pristine NFM and Bi-doped BNFM cathode (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><span> (g, h)) shows bright fringes corresponding to <a href="/topics/engineering/lattice-plane" title="Learn more about lattice planes from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">lattice planes</a><span> representing the <a href="/topics/engineering/crystalline-phase" title="Learn more about crystalline phase from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">crystalline phase</a> in the sample, while, the SAED pattern displayed in </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>(i) represents lattice plane of Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> coating layer.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0015"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X23034576-gr3.jpg" height="477" alt="Fig. 3" aria-describedby="ca0015"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X23034576-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (2MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (2MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X23034576-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="ca0015"><p id="sp0015"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. <span>TEM images (a-c), HR-TEM images (with inverse FFT images in the inset) (d-f), and corresponding <a href="/topics/materials-science/selected-area-diffraction" title="Learn more about SAED from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SAED</a> patterns (g-i) of prepared pristine NFM, BNFM and BNFM@Bi</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3.</sub></p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0085">X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis is conducted to investigate the structural compositions and the chemical valance states of as prepared cathode materials. The XPS survey spectra of NFM, BNFM and BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> measured over a binding energy (BE) range of 0 to 1200&nbsp;eV, as displayed in ESI Fig. S4 (a). All the three samples contain similar peaks related to the elements Na 1s, Ni 2p, Mn 2p, Fe 2p and O 1s, except for the extra peaks of Bi 4d and Bi 4f in BNFM and BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> samples. The XPS spectra of Na 1s is shown in ESI Fig. S4(b). Na 1s spectra shows the single valence state of Na 1s at the binding energy of 1069.30&nbsp;eV. The high resolution XPS spectra of Ni, Mn, Fe, Bi and O for Ni 2p are displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>. The Ni 2p spectrum (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a> (a)) of the three samples are deconvoluted into Ni 2p<sub>3/2</sub> and Ni 2p<sub>1/2</sub> core level domains corresponding to the binding energy range of 852.80&nbsp;eV and 870.50&nbsp;eV, respectively [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0220" name="bbb0220" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0220"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">44</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0225" name="bbb0225" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0225"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">45</span></span></a><span>]. Additionally, the spectra also consist of two intense shakeup satellite peaks observed at 859.30&nbsp;eV &amp; 877.36&nbsp;eV in all three samples. All of these <a href="/topics/engineering/calorific-value" title="Learn more about BE values from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">BE values</a> confirm the presence of Ni</span><sup>2+</sup> valance state of Ni [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0040" name="bbb0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">8</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0230" name="bbb0230" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0230"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">46</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0235" name="bbb0235" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0235"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">47</span></span></a>]. Similarly, the fitted spectra of Mn 2p for the three samples (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>(b)) also show a spin orbit doublets at the binding energies 640.50&nbsp;eV &amp; 652.04&nbsp;eV, which correspond to Mn 2p<sub>3/2</sub> and Mn 2p<sub>1/2</sub>. A small satellite peak occurs at binding energy 643.43&nbsp;eV. This signifies that Mn exist in Mn<sup>4+</sup><span> <a href="/topics/materials-science/oxidation-reaction" title="Learn more about oxidation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxidation</a> state [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0235" name="bbb0235" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0235"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[47]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0240" name="bbb0240" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0240"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[48]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0245" name="bbb0245" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0245"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[49]</span></span></a>]. In <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>(c), the Fe 2p spectra show the characteristic doublets at the binding energies 710.01&nbsp;eV &amp; 722.47&nbsp;eV corresponding to Fe 2p<sub>3/2</sub> and Fe 2p<sub>1/2</sub><span>, respectively. Also, low intensity satellite peaks at 715.60&nbsp;eV &amp; 729.60&nbsp;eV have been observed. These BE values and <a href="/topics/engineering/spectral-feature" title="Learn more about spectral features from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">spectral features</a> signify the presence of Fe</span><sup>3+</sup> state of iron in the three samples [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0250" name="bbb0250" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0250"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">50</span></span></a>]. The Bi 4f spectra (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>(d)) consists of two different valence states Bi<sup>3+</sup> and Bi<sup>5+</sup> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0255" name="bbb0255" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0255"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[51]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0260" name="bbb0260" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0260"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[52]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0265" name="bbb0265" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0265"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[53]</span></span></a>]. It can be seen in the deconvoluted spectra, Bi<sup>5+</sup> state is dominant in the BNFM cathode, which confirms the doping of Bi<sup>5+</sup> in the sample, whereas, in BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>, Bi<sup>3+</sup> is dominating. This may happen due to the Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> coating layer present in the BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0265" name="bbb0265" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0265"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">53</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0270" name="bbb0270" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0270"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">54</span></span></a>]. Apart from these, the deconvoluted Bi 4d spectra (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>(e)) show the doublet Bi 4d<sub>5/2</sub> and Bi 4d<sub>3/2</sub> at the binding energy values at 440.30&nbsp;eV and 463.66&nbsp;eV in BNFM and BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> spectra, further confirming the of Bi doping as well as the presence of Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> coating layer [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0275" name="bbb0275" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0275"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">55</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0280" name="bbb0280" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0280"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">56</span></span></a>]. Similarly, O1s spectra is also deconvoluted as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><span>(e). Pristine NFM shows three main peaks located at 527.54&nbsp;eV, 529.48&nbsp;eV and 533.83&nbsp;eV corresponding to metal‑oxygen bonds in lattice, <a href="/topics/materials-science/carbon-surface" title="Learn more about surface carbon from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">surface carbon</a> species such as carbonate/OH groups and organic carbon, respectively [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0285" name="bbb0285" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0285"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">57</span></span></a>]. However, it is observed that, in BNFM and BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> samples, the intensity of the carbonate contribution decreases by ~28&nbsp;% and metal‑oxygen bonding contribution increases significantly by ~20&nbsp;%. This result shows that the structural as well as surface modification in NFM cathode has remarkably decreased the surface oxygen contribution and increased the metal‑oxygen bonding contribution [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0285" name="bbb0285" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0285"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">57</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0290" name="bbb0290" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0290"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">58</span></span></a>].</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0020"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X23034576-gr4.jpg" height="540" alt="Fig. 4" aria-describedby="ca0020"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X23034576-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (814KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (814KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X23034576-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="ca0020"><p id="sp0020"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. <span><a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-photoelectron-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about XPS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XPS</a> spectra of (a) Ni 2P, (b) Mn 2P, (c) Fe 2P, (d) Bi 4f, (e) Bi 4d and (f) O1s for prepared pristine NFM, BNFM and BNFM@Bi</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3.</sub></p></span></span></figure></div><section id="s0045"><h3 id="st0065" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.1. Electrochemical performance</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0090"><span>The <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrochemical-property" title="Learn more about electrochemical properties from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical properties</a> of synthesized pristine, Bi-doped and Bi</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>-modified cathodes are assessed through the fabrication of half cells. These half cells are fabricated by employing the prepared cathodes (NFM, BNFM, and BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>) as the working electrodes and Na-metal as the reference electrode. The electrochemical (de)intercalation reactions are initially characterized by cyclic voltammetry measurement of the fabricated half cells, containing the three cathodes within the voltage range of 1.5&nbsp;V to 4.2&nbsp;V, as depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0025"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X23034576-gr5.jpg" height="323" alt="Fig. 5" aria-describedby="ca0025"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X23034576-gr5_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (799KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (799KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X23034576-gr5.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="ca0025"><p id="sp0025"><span class="label">Fig. 5</span>. (a-c) Cyclic voltammograms at 0.05&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>, (d-f) Charge discharge profile at 0.05-10C current rate for prepared pristine NFM, BNFM and BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3,</sub> respectively.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0095"><span>All the three cathodes show various distinct <a href="/topics/engineering/redox-couple" title="Learn more about redox couples from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">redox couples</a> indicating the several intermediate phase transformation during the cycling [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0295" name="bbb0295" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0295"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">59</span></span></a>]. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>(a-c) displays the cyclic voltammograms of the three samples at scanning rate of 0.05&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>, where three major reversible redox couples are clearly observed. At lower voltage, the redox couples located at 2.36/1.68&nbsp;V, 1.99/1.75&nbsp;V and 2.01/1.81&nbsp;V correspond to Mn<sup>4+/</sup>Mn<sup>3+</sup><span> <a href="/topics/materials-science/redox-process" title="Learn more about redox process from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">redox process</a>, as the Mn</span><sup>4+</sup><span> shows no redox behaviour above 2.5&nbsp;V in layered <a href="/topics/materials-science/oxide-compound" title="Learn more about oxides from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxides</a> [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0085" name="bbb0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">17</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0300" name="bbb0300" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0300"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">60</span></span></a>]. Moreover, within the voltage range of 2.8–4.2&nbsp;V, the two more pairs of redox peaks are observed. The redox pairs at 3.21/2.93&nbsp;V, 3.36/3.28&nbsp;V and 3.37/3.27&nbsp;V are attributed to Ni<sup>2+</sup>/Ni<sup>3+</sup> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0040" name="bbb0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">8</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0100" name="bbb0100" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0100"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">20</span></span></a>], while the pairs at 3.57/3.71&nbsp;V, 3.71/3.55&nbsp;V and 3.71/3.56&nbsp;V are attributed to Fe<sup>3+/</sup>Fe<sup>4+</sup> redox process for NFM, BNFM and BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>, respectively [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0305" name="bbb0305" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0305"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">61</span></span></a>]. However, it is obvious that the nature of pristine NFM is quite different from Bi-doped BNFM as well Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> coated BNFM samples. Although, the peak positions do not differ significantly, the peak intensity i.e., the current densities are entirely changed in the BNFM as well as BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> cathodes. After Bi doping, the peaks become sharper and more pronounced with high value of current density as compared to pristine one. The highest value of anodic current is observed ~0.07&nbsp;mA for pristine NFM, which increased to ~0.16&nbsp;mA in BNFM and 0.26&nbsp;mA in BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> samples. This happens because the doping causes the enhancement in the interlayer spacing between the transition metal layers, leading to fast diffusion of ions, which is evident in XRD and TEM analysis. However, the BNFM and BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> cathodes show almost similar nature. It is also observed that, the polarization in the peaks of pristine samples is high, which is significantly reduced in doped and coated samples. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>(a-c), the values of ΔV<sub>(Mn</sub><sup>3+/4+</sup><sub>)</sub>, ΔV<sub>(Ni</sub><sup>2+/3+</sup><sub>)</sub>, and ΔV<sub>(Fe</sub><sup>4+/3+</sup><sub>)</sub> in NFM cathode are obtained respectively ~0.69&nbsp;V, ~0.290&nbsp;V and&nbsp;~&nbsp;0.152&nbsp;V, which reduced to ~0.240&nbsp;V, ~0.072&nbsp;V and&nbsp;~&nbsp;0.14&nbsp;V, and&nbsp;~&nbsp;0.220&nbsp;V, ~0.070&nbsp;V and&nbsp;~&nbsp;0.13&nbsp;V, respectively for BNFM and BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span> cathodes. Since, the high <a href="/topics/materials-science/ionic-conductivity" title="Learn more about ionic conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ionic conductivity</a> and layered structure of Bi</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span> <a href="/topics/engineering/coating-material" title="Learn more about coating material from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">coating material</a> is compatible with layered structure cathode material, it significantly improves the diffusion of ions during the cycling. The combined effect of doping as well as Bi</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> coating in BNFM and BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span> facilitates the fast diffusion, low polarization and <a href="/topics/engineering/high-current-density" title="Learn more about high current density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">high current density</a> in the CV curves as compared to pristine NFM.</span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0100">Electrochemical behaviour of prepared cathodes is further investigated by galvanostatic charge/discharge method. All the three half cells are galvanostatically charged/discharged within the voltage window of 1.5&nbsp;V to 4.2&nbsp;V starting from lowest current range of 0.05C to highest current rate of 10C. The charge-discharge profiles of NFM, BNFM and BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> cathodes are presented in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>(d-f). Multiple charge/discharge plateaus can be seen in the charge/discharge profiles of the three cathodes, which associate to the different phase changes occurring during the cycling process and are in good agreement with the CV findings. The pristine NFM cathode exhibits the specific discharge capacity of 170 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, 152 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, 133 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, 110 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, 97 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, 62 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, 46 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> and 17 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, while BNFM cathode exhibits 181 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, 176 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, 154 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, 132 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, 116 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, 94 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, 65 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> and 32 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> and the BNFM@ Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> cathode renders 180 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, 175 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, 156 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, 134 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, 118 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, 96 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, 67 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> and 35 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at the current rate of 0.05C (14&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>), 0.1C (28&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>), 0.2C (56&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>), 0.5C (140&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>), 1C (280&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>), 2C (560&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>), 5C (1400&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>), and 10C (2800&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>), respectively.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0105">The rate performance of both half cells is displayed in the <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>(a). It is observed that, pristine NFM cathode shows lower specific discharge capacity with very fast capacity degradation, specially at higher current rate (i.e., 2C, 5C, 10C). On the other hand, Bi-doped and Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> coated cathodes show comparatively higher specific discharge capacity than pristine with low-capacity fading. Although, BNFM and BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> samples show comparative performance at lower current rate, but at higher current rate the latter one performs better. This improvement in the rate capability is obtained due to the effect of Bi-doping and Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> coating, where, former enlarges interlayer spacing and latter provides the ionic conducting channel as well as protects the particle from the contact of the electrolyte. The combined effect of Bi-doping and Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> coating facilitates fast diffusion of Na-ions within the transition metal layers resulting in superior rate capability.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0030"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X23034576-gr6.jpg" height="731" alt="Fig. 6" aria-describedby="ca0030"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X23034576-gr6_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X23034576-gr6.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="ca0030"><p id="sp0030"><span class="label">Fig. 6</span>. <span>(a) Rate performance, (b) <a href="/topics/materials-science/dielectric-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about EIS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">EIS</a> plots after 1st and last cycle, (c) cyclability plots, (d) the discharge curves with cycle, for prepared pristine NFM, BNFM and BNFM@Bi</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3.</sub> (e) Full cell performance of Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span> coated Bi-doped NFM cathode and hard <a href="/topics/engineering/carbon-anode" title="Learn more about carbon anode from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbon anode</a>.</span></p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0110">Moreover, the cyclability measurement of the three samples are also performed to further understand the advantages of Bi-doping as well as Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> coating on NFM particles. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>(c) shows the cyclability plots for the half cells NFM, BNFM and BNMF@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> cathodes at 1C. Initially, the pristine NFM cathode renders the specific discharge capacity of 98 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>. It is observed that, pristine NFM cathode suffers rapid capacity degradation during the cycling and nearly ~80&nbsp;% capacity loss has been observed within first 250&nbsp;cycles and after 400&nbsp;cycles the capacity of the cell has been lost completely. On the other hand, BNFM and BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> cathode provides the initial capacity ~116 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> and&nbsp;~&nbsp;118 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, respectively. After 1000&nbsp;cycles, BNFM shows 47&nbsp;% capacity retention, while, BNMF@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> shows 73&nbsp;% capacity retention of initial capacity. The average capacity fading rate is also calculated from cyclability data. It is found that, pristine NFM shows very fast fading rate&nbsp;~&nbsp;0.23 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>/cycle, whereas, BNFM and BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> show ~0.06 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>/cycle and&nbsp;~&nbsp;0.03 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>/cycle, respectively. This data shows that the capacity fading rate in NFM cathode is 3.8 times higher than BNFM and 7.6 times higher than BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>, which can be clearly seen in discharge profile of the three samples as displayed in the <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a> (d). From aforementioned results, it is clear that BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> cathode showed best electrochemical performance among all the three samples. Therefore, BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> cathode is further tested in full cell using hard carbon as anode. The <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a> (e) shows the rate performance and cycling performance of BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> in full cell. It is observed that full cell containing BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> cathode delivers the specific capacity of 151 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, 143 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, 121 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, 112 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, 104 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, 88 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> and 52 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, at the current rate of 0.05C (14&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>), 0.1C (28&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>), 0.2C (56&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>), 0.5C (140&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>), 1C (280&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>), 2C (560&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>) and 5C (1400&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>), respectively. Furthermore, the cell showed excellent cycling performance with ~82&nbsp;% capacity retention and&nbsp;~&nbsp;98&nbsp;% coulombic efficiency over 200&nbsp;cycles. Moreover, we have also compared the electrochemical performance of as prepared cathode materials with reported studies as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#t0015" name="bt0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="t0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 3</span></span></a>. From <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#t0015" name="bt0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="t0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 3</span></span></a>, it can be seen that dually modified sample shows better performance as compared to reported studies.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0115">Furthermore, EIS measurements are performed and examined for all three cathodes. The EIS plots of NFM, BNFM, and BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> cathodes before and after cycling is shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a><span> (b). The EIS spectra of all the three samples consist of depressed semicircles, which are actually two semicircles merged together. The intercept of the <a href="/topics/engineering/nyquist-plot" title="Learn more about Nyquist plot from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Nyquist plot</a> at the Z' axis depicts the bulk resistance R</span><sub>b</sub><span>, and the first semicircle indicates Na-ion diffusion through the <a href="/topics/engineering/solid-electrolyte-interface" title="Learn more about SEI from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SEI</a><span> and <a href="/topics/engineering/interface-layer" title="Learn more about CEI layers from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CEI layers</a> (R</span></span><sub>SEI+CEI</sub>) in the high frequency range, while the second is due to surface charge transfer (R<sub>CT</sub>) in the medium frequency range [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0310" name="bbb0310" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0310"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[62]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0315" name="bbb0315" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0315"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[63]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0320" name="bbb0320" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0320"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[64]</span></span></a><span>]. The Warburg resistance (W) for the Na-ion <a href="/topics/engineering/diffusion-process" title="Learn more about diffusion process from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion process</a> in the low frequency zone is represented by a sloping line [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0325" name="bbb0325" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0325"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">65</span></span></a>]. The EIS spectra of the three samples are fitted with NOVA 1.11 software, and the associated resistance values are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#t0010" name="bt0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="t0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 2</span></span></a>. The fitting result indicates that the R<sub>CT</sub> value for BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span> sample has a much lower <a href="/topics/engineering/charge-transfer-resistance" title="Learn more about charge transfer resistance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">charge transfer resistance</a> value (32.0&nbsp;Ω) than BNFM (60.1&nbsp;Ω) and pristine NFM (107.0&nbsp;Ω). The R</span><sub>CT</sub> value for the NFM cathode is increased from 107.0&nbsp;Ω to 464.0&nbsp;Ω after only 400&nbsp;cycles, whereas the R<sub>CT</sub> value for the BNFM and BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> samples is increased from 60.10&nbsp;Ω to 153.0&nbsp;Ω and 32&nbsp;Ω to 87&nbsp;Ω, respectively, after 1000&nbsp;cycles. This finding demonstrates the superior charge transfer rate of BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> throughout the cycling process, resulting in superior cycling stability, which is also compatible with CV and charge/discharge studies.</div><div class="tables frame-topbot rowsep-0 colsep-0" id="t0010"><span class="captions text-s"><span id="ca0050"><p id="sp0050"><span class="label">Table 2</span>. The values of cell resistance after fitting EIS spectra before &amp; after cycling and average Na-ion diffusivity during charging and discharging.</p></span></span><div (1C&nbsp;=&nbsp;120&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>)</td><td>92.1&nbsp;% retention after 300&nbsp;cycles at 0.5C</td><td rowspan="2">[<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0410" name="bbb0410" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0410"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">82</span></span></a>]</td></tr><tr><td>Na<sub>3.32</sub>Fe<sub>2.34</sub>(P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub>)<sub>2</sub>/C</td><td>100</td><td>0.1C</td><td>92.3&nbsp;% retention at 0.5C after 300&nbsp;cycles</td></tr><tr><td rowspan="3">14</td><td>Pristine NFM</td><td>170</td><td>0.05C</td><td>20&nbsp;% retention at 1C after 250&nbsp;cycles</td><td rowspan="3">This work</td></tr><tr><td>Bi doped BNFM</td><td>181</td><td>0.05C</td><td>47&nbsp;% retention at 1C after 1000&nbsp;cycles</td></tr><tr><td>Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> coated BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub></td><td>180</td><td>0.05C</td><td>73&nbsp;% retention at 1C after 1000&nbsp;cycles</td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></div></section><section id="s0050"><h3 id="st0070" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.2. Storage mechanism and diffusion analysis</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0120">To understand the storage mechanism and the excellent high-rate performance of BNFM and Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@BNFM over pristine NFM, the classic charge storage mechanism has been analyzed by measuring cyclic voltammetry at various scan rates. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>(a-c) show the cyclic voltammetry at various scan rates ranging from 0.05 to 0.5&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>. It is reported in literature that the peak current (<em>I</em><sub><em>p</em></sub>) obeys a function relationship with the voltage sweep rate (<em>ν</em>) as follows [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0330" name="bbb0330" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0330"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">66</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0335" name="bbb0335" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0335"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">67</span></span></a>].<span class="display"><span id="fo0015" class="formula"><span class="label">(3)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-24-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>,</mo><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>I</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>p</mi></msub><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>=</mo><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>a</mi><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3C5;</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>b</mi></msup></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="9.637ex" height="3.009ex" viewBox="0 -945.9 4149.5 1295.7" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.812ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2C"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(445,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-49"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(440,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-70"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1619,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(2675,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-61"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(3205,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3C5"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(540,362)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-62"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo is="true">,</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">I</mi><mi is="true">p</mi></msub><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><mi is="true">a</mi><msup is="true"><mi is="true">υ</mi><mi is="true">b</mi></msup></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-24"><math><mo is="true">,</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">I</mi><mi is="true">p</mi></msub><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><mi is="true">a</mi><msup is="true"><mi is="true">υ</mi><mi is="true">b</mi></msup></math></script></span></span></span><span>where, a is constant and b is <a href="/topics/engineering/power-law-exponent" title="Learn more about power law exponent from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">power law exponent</a>, which usually define the surface-induced capacitive contribution as well as diffusion-controlled process in the system. When the b&nbsp;=&nbsp;1, it means total surface controlled capacitive behaviour in capacity, while, b&nbsp;=&nbsp;0.5 indicates the total diffusion-controlled process. To quantify the value of b, the graph has been plotted between log sweep rate (</span><em>ν</em>) vs log peak current (<em>I</em><sub><em>P</em></sub>) for different anodic and cathodic peaks for all the three samples, as shown in the ESI Fig. S5. The b value is obtained by linear fitting of the data and the corresponding values are listed in the ESI Table S1. From Table S1, it is observed that b values lie between the 0.5 to 1, which concludes that both diffusion and capacitive controlled processes are going on during the charge storage. Also, it is observed that, b values are increasing in Bi-doped as well as Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> coated samples (in NFM, b values are close to 0.5, while, in BNFM and BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>, b values are close to 1; ESI Table S1). To further quantify the proportion of diffusive as well as capacitive contribution, the current (<em>i</em>) under certain potential (<em>V</em>) can be divided into two parts as follows <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0330" name="bbb0330" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0330"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">66</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0340" name="bbb0340" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0340"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">68</span></span></a><span class="display"><span id="fo0020" class="formula"><span class="label">(4)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-25-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mspace width=&quot;0.25em&quot; is=&quot;true&quot; /><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>i</mi><mfenced open=&quot;(&quot; close=&quot;)&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>V</mi></mfenced><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>=</mo><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>k</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>1</mn></msub><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3BD;</mi><mo linebreak=&quot;badbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>+</mo><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>k</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></msub><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3BD;</mi><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>1</mn><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>/</mo><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></mrow></msup></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="19.992ex" height="3.009ex" viewBox="0 -945.9 8607.6 1295.7" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.812ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="translate(521,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-31"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(4175,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3BD"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(4928,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(5929,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-6B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(521,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(6904,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3BD"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(541,362)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-31"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(353,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2F"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(707,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-25"><math><mspace width="0.25em" is="true"></mspace><mi is="true">i</mi><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mi is="true">V</mi></mfenced><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">1</mn></msub><mi is="true">ν</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><msup is="true"><mi is="true">ν</mi><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup></math></script></span></span></span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0035"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X23034576-gr7.jpg" height="605" alt="Fig. 7" aria-describedby="ca0035"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X23034576-gr7_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (2MB)"><span
