u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X23034576-gr7.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="ca0035"><p id="sp0035"><span class="label">Fig. 7</span>. <span><span><a href="/topics/engineering/kinetics-analysis" title="Learn more about Kinetics analysis from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Kinetics analysis</a><span> of <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> storage behaviour. (a-c) </span></span><a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about CV from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CV</a> curves at various scan rates (0.05–0.5&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s</span><sup>−1</sup><span>), (d-f) ratio of capacitive behaviour to <a href="/topics/engineering/diffusion-behavior" title="Learn more about diffusion behaviour from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion behaviour</a>, (g) GITT plots for charging/discharging condition, and (h-i) variation of D</span><sub>Na</sub><sup>+</sup> with voltage for prepared pristine NFM, BNFM and BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3.</sub></p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0125">Here, <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-26-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>k</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>1</mn></msub><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3BD;</mi></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="3.498ex" height="2.317ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 1505.9 997.6" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-6B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(521,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-31"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(975,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3BD"></use></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">1</mn></msub><mi is="true">ν</mi></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-26"><math><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">1</mn></msub><mi is="true">ν</mi></math></script></span> and <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-27-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>k</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></msub><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3BD;</mi><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>1</mn><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>/</mo><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></mrow></msup></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="6.221ex" height="2.779ex" viewBox="0 -945.9 2678.5 1196.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-6B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(521,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(975,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3BD"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(541,362)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-31"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(353,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2F"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(707,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><msup is="true"><mi is="true">ν</mi><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-27"><math><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><msup is="true"><mi is="true">ν</mi><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup></math></script></span> represent capacitive and diffusion-controlled charge, respectively. The values of <em>k</em><sub><em>1</em></sub> and <em>k</em><sub><em>2</em></sub> are obtained by linearly fitted plot of <em>i</em>(<em>V</em>)/ν<sup>1/2</sup> as a function of ν<sup>1/2</sup>. <em>k</em><sub><em>1</em></sub> and <em>k</em><sub><em>2</em></sub> are related to the slope and intercept of fitted lines, respectively. ESI Fig. S5 represents the linearly fitted plots <em>i</em>(<em>V</em>)/ν<sup>1/2</sup> vs ν<sup>1/2</sup> at various voltages during sodiation and desodiation for all the three samples. The obtained capacitive charge storage contributions to total sodium storage at a scan rate of 0.05&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup> are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>(d-f). As expected, the capacitive behaviour in pristine NFM is found ~51&nbsp;%, which subsequently enhanced to ~68&nbsp;% in BNFM and&nbsp;~&nbsp;81&nbsp;% in BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>. The decreasing diffusion-controlled behaviour and increasing capacitive behaviour in Bi-doped and Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> coated samples is the result of the increased interplanar distance due to Bi-doping as well as Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> coating, which not only facilitate rapid ion diffusion during intercalation/deintercalation, but also coating layer protects the particles from malignant side reaction by preventing the contact of electrolyte. Also, the Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span> coating layer helps in fast ion diffusion due to its high <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/ion-current" title="Learn more about ionic conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ionic conductivity</a>. Thus, the combined effect of Bi-doping and Bi</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> coating enhances the capacitive behaviour, which favours the fast intercalation process, leading to high-rate capability.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0130">Quantitative study of capacitive and diffusive behaviours in the prepared cathode materials reveals that the latter is predominate in the samples, and further increases after Bi-doping and Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span> coating. Now, to confirm this result, the values of <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffusion-coefficient" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficient from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficient</a> of Na-ions in as prepared cathode materials are investigated by galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) analysis. This technique involves applying a constant current pulse at a low rate (C/20) for 30&nbsp;min, followed by 30&nbsp;min of rest time, to half cells having NMF, BNFM, as well as BNFM@Bi</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> cathodes with the same area and mass loading. The ESI Fig. S7 displays the GITT charge/discharge patterns for the three electrodes over a shared voltage range of 1.5&nbsp;V to 4.2&nbsp;V. Using the Weppner and Huggins method, the sodium ion transport rate is determined as follows<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0250" name="bbb0250" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0250"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">50</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0345" name="bbb0345" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0345"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">69</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0350" name="bbb0350" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0350"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">70</span></span></a>;.<span class="display"><span id="fo0025" class="formula"><span class="label">(5)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-28-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mspace width=&quot;0.25em&quot; is=&quot;true&quot; /><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>D</mi><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;italic&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>Na</mi><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>+</mo></msup></msub><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>=</mo><mfrac is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>4</mn><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>L</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></msup></mrow><mi mathvariant=&quot;italic&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3C0;&amp;#x3C4;</mi></mfrac><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mfenced open=&quot;[&quot; close=&quot;]&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;><mfrac is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;italic&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x394;E</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>s</mi></msub><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;italic&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x394;E</mi><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3C4;</mi></msub></mfrac></mfenced><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></msup></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="20.023ex" height="5.086ex" viewBox="0 -1442.7 8621.2 2189.9" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -1.735ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"></g><g is="true" transform="translate(250,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-44"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(828,-239)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-4E"></use><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-61" x="803" y="0"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(942,290)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(2858,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(3637,0)"><g transform="translate(397,0)"><rect stroke="none" width="1276" height="60" x="0" y="220"></rect><g is="true" transform="translate(60,405)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-34"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(353,0)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-4C"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(481,290)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(281,-345)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3C0"></use><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3C4" x="570" y="0"></use></g></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(5431,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJSZ2-5B"></use><g is="true" transform="translate(472,0)"><g transform="translate(120,0)"><rect stroke="none" width="1550" height="60" x="0" y="220"></rect><g is="true" transform="translate(72,514)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAINI-394"></use><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-45" x="818" y="0"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1100,-107)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-73"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(60,-411)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAINI-394"></use><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-45" x="818" y="0"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1100,-107)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3C4"></use></g></g></g></g><use xlink:href="#MJSZ2-5D" x="2262" y="-1"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(2735,877)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mspace width="0.25em" is="true"></mspace><msub is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">Na</mi><mo is="true">+</mo></msup></msub><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">4</mn><msup is="true"><mi is="true">L</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msup></mrow><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">πτ</mi></mfrac><msup is="true"><mfenced open="[" close="]" is="true"><mfrac is="true"><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">ΔE</mi><mi is="true">s</mi></msub><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">ΔE</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">τ</mi></msub></mfrac></mfenced><mn is="true">2</mn></msup></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-28"><math><mspace width="0.25em" is="true"></mspace><msub is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">Na</mi><mo is="true">+</mo></msup></msub><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">4</mn><msup is="true"><mi is="true">L</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msup></mrow><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">πτ</mi></mfrac><msup is="true"><mfenced open="[" close="]" is="true"><mfrac is="true"><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">ΔE</mi><mi is="true">s</mi></msub><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">ΔE</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">τ</mi></msub></mfrac></mfenced><mn is="true">2</mn></msup></math></script></span></span></span><span>where, L and τ stand for the electrode's thickness and the current pulse's <a href="/topics/engineering/relaxation-time" title="Learn more about relaxation time from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">relaxation time</a>, respectively. </span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-29-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;italic&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x394;E</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>s</mi></msub></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="4.62ex" height="2.432ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 1989 1047.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAINI-394"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-45" x="818" y="0"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1557,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-73"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">ΔE</mi><mi is="true">s</mi></msub></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-29"><math><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">ΔE</mi><mi is="true">s</mi></msub></math></script></span> is the steady-state potential, while <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-30-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;italic&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x394;E</mi><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3C4;</mi></msub></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="4.698ex" height="2.432ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 2022.9 1047.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAINI-394"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-45" x="818" y="0"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1557,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3C4"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">ΔE</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">τ</mi></msub></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-30"><math><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">ΔE</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">τ</mi></msub></math></script></span> is the potential difference during the constant current pulse, eliminating the IR drop (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>(g)). <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. 7</span></span></a><span>(h, i) show the estimated <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffusivity" title="Learn more about diffusivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusivity</a> (D</span><sub>Na</sub><sup>+</sup><span>) of the three cathodes drawn against cell potential during the sodiation and desodiation processes, respectively. The average values of <a href="/topics/engineering/apparent-diffusion" title="Learn more about apparent diffusion from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">apparent diffusion</a> coefficient (D</span><sub>Na</sub><sup>+</sup>) during charging and discharging process are obtained ~2.50&nbsp;×&nbsp;10<sup>−10</sup>&nbsp;cm<sup>2</sup>&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup> and 3.75&nbsp;×&nbsp;10<sup>−9</sup>&nbsp;cm<sup>2</sup>&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup> for pristine NFM cathode, respectively. For Bi-doped BNFM cathode, it is obtained ~8.80&nbsp;×&nbsp;10<sup>−9</sup>&nbsp;cm<sup>2</sup>&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup> and 2.14&nbsp;×&nbsp;10<sup>−8</sup>&nbsp;cm<sup>2</sup>&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>, whereas, for BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> it is found ~1.09&nbsp;×&nbsp;10<sup>−8</sup>&nbsp;cm<sup>2</sup>&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup> and&nbsp;~&nbsp;1.12&nbsp;×&nbsp;10<sup>−8</sup>&nbsp;cm<sup>2</sup>&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>, respectively. The combined effect of Bi-doping and Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> coating significantly enhance the interplanar spacing and provide effective protection to the cathode particles against direct contact with the electrolyte, leading to improved electrochemical performance. The improved electrochemical performance can be attributed to the reduced charge transfer barrier at the interface and enhanced Na-ion insertion and de-insertion within intermediate slabs. These findings suggest that Bi-doping and Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> coating can be promising strategies to improve the electrochemical performance of BNFM@ Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> cathode.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0135">Furthermore, the post-mortem analysis of all the three cells was performed after complete cycles, in order to confirm the advantage of Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> coating. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0040" name="bf0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a> shows the after cycling SEM images of NFM, BNFM and BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span> cathode. The pristine NFM cathode clearly shows the huge cracks on the <a href="/topics/engineering/cathode-surface" title="Learn more about cathode surface from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">cathode surface</a> (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0040" name="bf0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a> (a)). This happens due to the sluggish ion kinetics, which causes aeolotropic stress during cycling. From these cracks, electrolyte further infiltrates and reacts with cathode, leading to fast capacity fading. Conversely, BNFM has fewer surface cracks, although deteriorated cathode particles are present as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0040" name="bf0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a> (b). Since Bi-doping improved the Na-ion diffusion rate, there are fewer cracks because there is less stress during cycling. However, after many cycles, the particles deteriorate because of side reactions between the electrode particles and the electrolyte. In BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>, no cracks and particle deterioration are observed (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0040" name="bf0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a> (c)). This happens due to the combined effect of Bi-doping as well as Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span> coating, which not only improve the <a href="/topics/engineering/diffusion-coefficient" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficient from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficient</a>, but also coating layer protects the particles from side reactions, making BNFM@Bi</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> as a suitable cathode material for high performance sodium ion battery.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0040"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X23034576-gr8.jpg" height="221" alt="Fig. 8" aria-describedby="ca0040"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X23034576-gr8_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X23034576-gr8.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="ca0040"><p id="sp0040"><span class="label">Fig. 8</span>. Post-mortem analysis: SEM images of (a) NFM, (b) BNFM and (c) BNFM@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> after cycling.</p></span></span></figure></div></section></section><section id="s0055"><h2 id="st0075" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">4. Conclusion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0140">Herein, a biphasic (P2/O3) cobalt-free layered Na[Ni<sub>0.55</sub>Mn<sub>0.35</sub>Fe<sub>0.1</sub>]O<sub>2</sub> (NFM) cathode has been successfully synthesized and dual (structural as well as surface) modifications have been performed. Bi<sup>5+</sup> is doped into pure NFM in order to tune the P2/O3 phase, whereas, a thin layer of Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> is coated on surface of the Bi<sup>5+</sup>-doped NFM to modify the surface. The structure, morphology, and electrochemical performance of produced samples are examined and compared using a variety of characterization methods. Initially, O3 phase was dominating with a phase fraction of 78.86&nbsp;%, whilst P2 phase is 21.14&nbsp;%. After the addition of Bi<sup>5+</sup><span>, the P2-content grew to up to 47.14&nbsp;%, while the O3 phase stayed at 52.86&nbsp;% in the BNFM sample. TEM image confirms a thin layer of the thickness&nbsp;~&nbsp;6&nbsp;nm is wrapped on the surface of NFM particle. Sodium storage and diffusion analysis revels that, dual modification leads to high <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffusion-coefficient" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficient from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficient</a> and increased surface controlled capacitive behaviour in the BNFM@Bi</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> sample. The pristine NFM cathode exhibits the specific discharge capacity of 170 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, while Bi-doped cathode exhibits 181 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, and Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> coated cathode renders 180 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>. It is observed that, pristine NFM cathode suffers rapid capacity degradation and nearly ~80&nbsp;% capacity loss within first 250&nbsp;cycles. After 1000&nbsp;cycles, BNFM shows 47&nbsp;% capacity retention, while, BNMF@Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> shows 73&nbsp;% capacity retention of initial capacity.</div></section><section id="s0060"><h2 id="st0080" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">CRediT authorship contribution statement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0145"><strong>Raghvendra Mishra:</strong> Conceptualization, Data curation, Formal analysis, Investigation, Methodology, Resources, Software, Validation, Visualization, Writing – original draft, Writing – review &amp; editing. <strong>Rupesh K. Tiwari:</strong> Resources. <strong>Anupam Patel:</strong> Resources. <strong>Anurag Tiwari:</strong> Resources. <strong>Rajendra K. Singh:</strong> Conceptualization, Formal analysis, Funding acquisition, Investigation, Project administration, Resources, Supervision, Writing – review &amp; editing.</div></section></div><section id="coi0005"><h2 id="st0085" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Declaration of competing interest</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0150">The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.</div></section><section id="ac0005"><h2 id="st0090" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Acknowledgements</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0155">One of the authors (R.K. Singh) thankfully acknowledges the financial assistance by <span id="gts0005">SERB</span>, New Delhi, India under IMPRINT ΙΙ C and IoE, BHU, Varanasi India, to carry out the research work. R. Sun</div><div id="ref-id-rf0370" class="title text-m">Highly stable Na2/3(Mn0.54Ni0.13Co0.13)O2 cathode modified by atomic layer deposition for sodium-ion batteries</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">ChemSusChem, 8 (2015), pp. 2537-2543, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1002/cssc.201500155" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="reference" id="or0030"><div class="other-ref"><span>Batteries HS, Feng Y, Huang Q. Accepted Manuscript n.d.</span></div><div class="ReferenceLinks u-font-sans"><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://scholar.google.com/scholar?q=Batteries%20HS%2C%20Feng%20Y%2C%20Huang%20Q.%20Accepted%20Manuscript%20n.d." target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Google Scholar</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div></span></li><li><span class="label u-font-sans"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bbb0405" id="ref-id-bb0405" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=references:type=anchor:name=citation-name"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[81]</span></span></a></span><span class="reference" id="rf0375"><div class="contribution"><div class="authors u-font-sans">Q. Liu, <em> et al.</em></div><div id="ref-id-rf0375" class="title text-m">Surface stabilization of O3-type layered oxide cathode to protect the anode of sodium ion batteries for superior lifespan</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">IScience, 19 (2019), pp. 244-254, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1016/j.isci.2019.07.029" target="_blank"><span data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=references:type=anchor:name=citation-name"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[82]</span></span></a></span><span class="reference" id="rf0380"><div class="contribution"><div class="authors u-font-sans">M. Chen, L. Chen, Z. Hu, Q. Liu, B. Zhang, Y. Hu, <em> et al.</em></div><div id="ref-id-rf0380" class="title text-m">Carbon-coated Na3.32Fe2.34(P2O7)2 cathode material for high-rate and long-life sodium-ion batteries</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">Adv. Mater., 29 (2017), pp. 1-8, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1002/adma.201605535" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">10.1002/adma.201605535</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path anchor-primary anchor-icon-left anchor-with-icon" href="/science/article/pii/S1434841116309037/pdfft?md5=471409c45389d545813fa31e61a1367b&amp;pid=1-s2.0-S1434841116309037-main.pdf" target="_blank" rel="nofollow" aria-describedby="ref-id-rf0380"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 35 32" height="20" class="icon icon-pdf-multicolor"><path d="M7 .362h17.875l6.763 6.1V31.64H6.948V16z" stroke="#000" stroke-width=".703" fill="#fff"></path><path d="M.167 2.592H22.39V9.72H.166z" fill="#da0000"></path><path fill="#fff9f9" d="M5.97 3.638h1.62c1.053 0 1.483.677 1.488 1.564.008.96-.6 1.564-1.492 1.564h-.644v1.66h-.977V3.64m.977.897v1.34h.542c.27 0 .596-.068.596-.673-.002-.6-.32-.667-.596-.667h-.542m3.8.036v2.92h.35c.933 0 1.223-.448 1.228-1.462.008-1.06-.316-1.45-1.23-1.45h-.347m-.977-.94h1.03c1.68 0 2.523.586 2.534 2.39.01 1.688-.607 2.4-2.534 2.4h-1.03V3.64m4.305 0h2.63v.934h-1.657v.894H16.6V6.4h-1.56v2.026h-.97V3.638"></path><path d="M19.462 13.46c.348 4.274-6.59 16.72-8.508 15.792-1.82-.85 1.53-3.317 2.92-4.366-2.864.894-5.394 3.252-3.837 3.93 2.113.895 7.048-9.25 9.41-15.394zM14.32 24.874c4.767-1.526 14.735-2.974 15.152-1.407.824-3.157-13.72-.37-15.153 1.407zm5.28-5.043c2.31 3.237 9.816 7.498 9.788 3.82-.306 2.046-6.66-1.097-8.925-4.164-4.087-5.534-2.39-8.772-1.682-8.732.917.047 1.074 1.307.67 2.442-.173-1.406-.58-2.44-1.224-2.415-1.835.067-1.905 4.46 1.37 9.065z" fill="#f91d0a"></path></svg><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View PDF</span></span></a><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S1434841116309037" aria-describedby="ref-id-rf0380"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View article</span></span></a><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?title=Carbon-coated%20Na3.32Fe2.342%20cathode%20material%20for%20high-rate%20and%20long-life%20sodium-ion%20batteries&amp;publication_year=2017&amp;author=M.%20Chen&amp;author=L.%20Chen&amp;author=Z.%20Hu&amp;author=Q.%20Liu&amp;author=B.%20Zhang&amp;author=Y.%20Hu" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div></span></li></ol></section></section></div><div id="section-cited-by"><section aria-label="Cited by" class="ListArticles preview"><div class="PageDivider"></div><header id="citing-articles-header"><h2 class="u-h4 u-margin-l-ver u-font-serif">Cited by (14)</h2></header><div aria-describedby="citing-articles-header"><div class="citing-articles u-margin-l-bottom"><ul><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-0-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S2095495625002402"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Emerging modification strategies for layered Fe-based oxide cathodes toward high-performance sodium-ion batteries</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Journal of Energy Chemistry</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-0-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-0" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0015">Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) have the advantages of environmental friendliness, cost-effectiveness, and high energy density, which are considered one of the most promising candidates for lithium-ion batteries (LIBs). The cathode materials influence the cost and energy output of SIBs. Therefore, the development of advanced cathode materials is crucial for the practical application of SIBs. Among various cathode materials, layered transition metal oxides (LTMOs) have received widespread attention owing to their straightforward preparation, abundant availability, and cost-competitiveness. Notably, layered Fe-based oxide cathodes are deemed to be one of the most promising candidates for the lowest price and easy-to-improve performance. Nevertheless, the challenges such as severe phase transitions, sluggish diffusion kinetics and interfacial degradation pose significant hurdles in achieving high-performance cathodes for SIBs. This review first briefly outlines the classification of layered structures and the working principle of layered oxides. Then, recent advances in modification strategies employed to address current issues with layered iron-based oxide cathodes are systematically reviewed, including ion doping, biphasic engineering and surface modification. Furthermore, the review not only outlines the prospects and development directions for layered Fe-based oxide cathodes but also provides novel insights and directions for future research endeavors for SIBs.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-1-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S2405829725002120"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Towards high-performance sodium-ion batteries: A comprehensive review on Na&lt;inf&gt;x&lt;/inf&gt;Ni&lt;inf&gt;y&lt;/inf&gt;Fe&lt;inf&gt;z&lt;/inf&gt;Mn&lt;inf&gt;1−(&lt;/inf&gt;&lt;inf&gt;y&lt;/inf&gt;&lt;inf&gt;+&lt;/inf&gt;&lt;inf&gt;z&lt;/inf&gt;&lt;inf&gt;)&lt;/inf&gt;O&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt; cathode materials</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Energy Storage Materials</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-1-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-1" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="spara021">Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are potential candidates for next-generation grid-scale energy storage owing to their safety as well as the abundance of sodium resources. Further progress in SIB technology demands the advancement of cathode materials with outstanding performance. Among various cathode materials, layered transition metal oxides based on Ni, Fe, and Mn (NaNFM) have recently received great attention by combining the positive features of each of them. This review focuses on the most current developments in the study and design of NaNFM (Na<em><sub>x</sub></em>Ni<em><sub>y</sub></em>Fe<em><sub>z</sub></em>Mn<sub>1−(<em><sub>y</sub></em>+</sub><em><sub>z</sub></em><sub>)</sub>O<sub>2</sub>) as a cathode material for SIBs, including synthesis methods, crystal structure/structural evolution during charge–discharging, and the effect of different molar ratios. Adjusting the transition elements enables formation in several phases that promote Na-ion diffusion, resulting in high-rate capability and cycle stability. Moreover, key strategies to improve the electrochemical performance through doping and surface modifications are discussed. Future optimization of these materials shows potential for enormous opportunities for implementing cost-effective and high-performance energy -storage technologies.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-2-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0021979724022161"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Engineering a superionic conductor surface enables fast Na&lt;sup&gt;+&lt;/sup&gt; transport kinetics for high-stable layered oxide cathode</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Journal of Colloid and Interface Science</div><div class="CitedSection u-margin-s-top"><div class="u-margin-s-left"><div class="cite-header u-text-italic u-font-sans">Citation Excerpt :</div><p class="u-font-serif text-xs">In addition, interspersing ZrO2 nanoparticles on the surface of layered oxide is also beneficial for the enhancement of electrochemical performance at high-voltage [9]. Bi2O3 [10], SnO2 [11], and TiO2 [12] etc. functional coating interphase have also been proven effective in improving the stability of the surface between cathodes and electrolyte and inhibiting surface parasitic reactions during cycles. Although these oxides layer can effectively enhance the interfacial stability of electrodes, the inherent inert characteristics of coating layer typically impede ion transfer across the interface, increasing the charge transfer impedance.</p></div></div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-2-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-2" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0020">Unstable cathode/electrolyte interphase and severe interfacial side reaction have long been identified as the main cause for the failure of layered oxide cathode during fast charging and long-term cycling for rechargeable sodium-ion batteries. Here, we report a superionic conductor (Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, NVP) bonding surface strategy for O3-type layered NaNi<sub>1/3</sub>Fe<sub>1/3</sub>Mn<sub>1/3</sub>O<sub>2</sub> (NFM) cathode to suppress electrolyte corrosion and near-surface structure deconstruction, especially at high operating potential. The strong bonding affinity at the NVP/NFM contact interface stabilizes the crystal structure by inhibiting surface parasitic reactions and transition metal dissolution, thus significantly improving the phase change reversibility at high desodiation state and prolonging the lifespan of NFM cathode. Due to the high-electron-conductivity of NFM, the redox activity of NVP is also enhanced to provide additional capacity. Therefore, benefiting from the fast ion transport kinetics and electrochemical Na<sup>+</sup>-storage activity of NVP, the composite NFM@NVP electrode displays a high initial coulombic efficiency of 95.5&nbsp;% at 0.1 C and excellent rate capability (100&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 20&nbsp;C) within high cutoff voltage of 4.2&nbsp;V. The optimized cathode also delivers preeminent cyclic stability with ∼80&nbsp;% capacity retention after 500 cycles at 2&nbsp;C. This work sheds light on a facile and universal strategy on improving interphase stability to develop fast-charging and sustainable batteries.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-3-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0013468624006984"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Rational design of an optimal Al-substituted layered oxide cathode for Na-ion batteries</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Electrochimica Acta</div><div class="CitedSection u-margin-s-top"><div class="u-margin-s-left"><div class="cite-header u-text-italic u-font-sans">Citation Excerpt :</div><p class="u-font-serif text-xs">At a charge-discharge rate of 0.1C, both the cathodes show specific capacities close to 195 mAh g−1 due to the higher Ni concentrations (Fig. 6(a1) and (b1)). This is validated by multiple peaks appearing in their respective CV and dQ/dV vs V plots above 3 V (Figs. S8 and S9) that correspond to Ni2+/4+ redox couples [52,55–57]. In contrast, the lower concentration of Ni2+ in NMA4 and NMA6 cathodes limited their specific capacity to 170 mAh g−1 at 0.1C. Moreover, unlike NMA3-P3 and NMA5-P3, more than 50 % of the specific capacity in NMA4-P3 and NMA6-P3 is due to the activation of Mn3+/4+ redox couples, which could lead to lower cyclic performance in the latter.</p></div></div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-3-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-3" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="spara010">Layered oxide cathodes, a promising avenue for Na-ion batteries, hold the highest potential for commercialization. Herein, we delve into the structural and electrochemical properties of Al-substituted layered oxides in our quest to pinpoint the optimal cathode composition in the Na<sub>3/4</sub>(Mn-Al-Ni)O<sub>2</sub> pseudo-ternary system. The cathode materials investigated were synthesized in three distinct phase configurations, which include two monophasic configurations with P3 and P2-type structures and a third biphasic cathode with equal proportions of P3 and P2 phases. The fractions of the P3 and P2 type phases in the cathode materials were manipulated by adjusting the calcination temperature. The varying concentration of Mn<sup>3+</sup> and Mn<sup>4+</sup>, confirmed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, was found to impact the cyclic stability of these materials significantly. During electrochemical testing, the P3 cathodes showed impressive rate performance and exhibited an excellent specific capacity of 195 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 0.1C. Regarding cyclic performance, the biphasic cathodes consistently outperformed their monophasic counterparts, with P3/P2-Na<sub>0.75</sub>Mn<sub>0.50</sub>Ni<sub>0.25</sub>Al<sub>0.25</sub>O<sub>2</sub> exhibiting 82 % capacity retention after 300 cycles. Analysis of <em>operando</em> Synchrotron XRD data revealed an absence of P3 to O3 type phase transition in the cathodes even at low voltages where large structural variations to the unit cell structure were observed. The absence of P3 to O3 transformations and the superior electrochemical performance of Na<sub>0.75</sub>Mn<sub>0.50</sub>Ni<sub>0.25</sub>Al<sub>0.25</sub>O<sub>2</sub> underlines the importance of Al substitution and P3/P2 biphasic structure in enhancing the electrochemical performance of layered oxides.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-4-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1002/celc.202400657" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Enhancing Sodium Ion Battery Performance through Biphasic Layered Oxide Cathodes</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></h3><div>2025, ChemElectroChem</div></div><div class="buttons"></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-5-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1002/adfm.202404938" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Challenges and Strategies toward Manganese Hexacyanoferrate for High-Performance Sodium-Ion Batteries</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902     const pendoData = {"visitor":{"pageName":"SD:product:journal:article","pageType":"CP-CA","pageProduct":"SD","pageLanguage":"en","pageEnvironment":"prod","accessType":"ae:ANON_IP","countryCode":"GB"},"account":{"id":"ae:11279","name":"ae:Imperial College London"},"events":{}};;
    pendoData.events = {
      ready: function () {
        pendo.addAltText();
      },
    };
    function runPendo(data, options) {
  const {
    firstDelay,
    maxRetries,
    urlPrefix,
    urlSuffix,
    apiKey
  } = options;
  (function (apiKey) {
    (function (p, e, n, d, o) {
      var v, w, x, y, z;
      o = p[d] = p[d] || {};
      o._q = [];
      v = ['initialize', 'identify', 'updateOptions', 'pageLoad'];
      for (w = 0, x = v.length; w < x; ++w) (function (m) {
        o[m] = o[m] || function () {
          o._q[m === v[0] ? 'unshift' : 'push']([m].concat([].slice.call(arguments, 0)));
        };
      })(v[w]);
      y = e.createElement(n);
      y.async = !0;
      y.src = urlPrefix + apiKey + urlSuffix;
      z = e.getElementsByTagName(n)[0];
      z.parentNode.insertBefore(y, z);
    })(window, document, 'script', 'pendo');
    pendo.addAltText = function () {
      var target = document.querySelector('body');
      var observer = new MutationObserver(function (mutations) {
        mutations.forEach(function (mutation) {
          if (mutation?.addedNodes?.length) {
            if (mutation.addedNodes[0]?.className?.includes("_pendo-badge")) {
              const badge = mutation.addedNodes[0];
              const altText = badge?.attributes['aria-label']?.value || 'Feedback';
              const pendoBadgeImage = pendo.dom(`#${badge?.attributes?.id.value} img`);
              if (pendoBadgeImage.length) {
                pendoBadgeImage[0]?.setAttribute('alt', altText);
              }
            }
          }
        });
      });
      var config = {
        attributeFilter: ['data-layout'],
        attributes: true,
        childList: true,
        characterData: true,
        subtree: false
      };
      observer.observe(target, config);
    };
  })(apiKey);
  (function watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay, retryAttempt) {
    if (data.visitor.id) {
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else if (typeof pageDataTracker === 'object' && typeof pageDataTracker.getVisitorId === 'function' && pageDataTracker.getVisitorId()) {
      data.visitor.id = pageDataTracker.getVisitorId();
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else {
      if (retryAttempt > 0) {
        return setTimeout(function () {
          watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay * 2, retryAttempt - 1);
        }, nextDelay);
      }
      pendo.initialize(data);
      console.debug(`gave up ... pendo initialized`);
    }
  })(firstDelay, maxRetries);
}
    window.addPendoScript = () => {
      runPendo(pendoData, {
        firstDelay: 100,
        maxRetries: 5,
        urlPrefix: 'https://cdn.pendo.io/agent/static/',
        urlSuffix: '/pendo.js',
        apiKey: 'd6c1d995-bc7e-4e53-77f1-2ea4ecbb9565',
      });
      window.addPendoScript = () => {};
    };
    addEventListener('load', () => window.addPendoScript());
  </script>
